title: Obama strikes cautious balance on Egypt
content:
The administration grapples with the reality that Morsi had alienated Egyptians . | REUTERS Obama 's cautious balance on Egypt
The ouster of Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi on Wednesday by the Egyptian military and a broad coalition of opposition figures presents a stark choice for President Barack Obama .
He can stand by the formalities of the democratic process — or he can embrace the kind of “ people power ” revolt that has driven out a series of authoritarian leaders in that part of the world .
The president ’ s first somber statement , released hours after the military seized power , appeared to adopt both approaches , straddling the divide between the passion on the streets of Cairo and the principles of democracy .
“ [ W ] e are deeply concerned by the decision of the Egyptian Armed Forces to remove President [ Morsi ] and suspend the Egyptian constitution , ” Obama said . “ I now call on the Egyptian military to move quickly and responsibly to return full authority back to a democratically elected civilian government as soon as possible . ”
He added : “ No transition to democracy comes without difficulty , but in the end it must stay true to the will of the people . ”
It was an early sign that pragmatism may carry the day , as the Obama administration grapples with the reality that Morsi — while democratically elected — had alienated too many Egyptians to continue in office .
“ In the wake of Mubarak ’ s overthrow , the administration rationalized a democratic election which was essentially taken hostage by an anti-democratic party , ” said former State Department official Aaron David Miller .
” Now , the task is how to rationalize what by all inclinations , regardless of the tensions and the motives , is the overturning of that election by the military . … It ’ s a real paradox , and the administration will continue to have a hard time , ” he said .
However , the televised tableau of Egyptian army chief of staff Abdel Fattah Al-Sisi flanked by an unusually diverse assembly of figures from Egyptian society could ease the U.S. predicament , some experts said .
“ It is an ouster by the military and therefore , technically a coup [ but ] this was a totally unique kind of coup , ” said Washington-based Mideast analyst Hussein Ibish . “ It was amazing who was on that podium . ”
The high-profile backers of the military announcement and interim government ran the gamut from the police to the bureaucracy to former International Atomic Energy Agency chief Mohammed El-Baradei , who has emerged as a central leader of the opposition .
“ You had the chosen representatives of all the non-Islamist forces , one after another , endorsing this roadmap and framework for the future , ” Ibish noted . “ What I think the administration should say is that we respect democratic processes , but we also respect the will of the people . ”
One key question is whether Morsi ’ s Muslim Brotherhood backers will react to the coup with violence — and how the U.S. will respond if they do .
In his Tuesday night speech , Morsi seemed to be girding for a fight . “ If the price for safeguarding legitimacy is my blood , then I am prepared to sacrifice my blood for the cause of safety and legitimacy of this homeland , ” he declared .
“ There ’ s a real danger of a hysterical reaction , ” Ibish warned . “ He knew he was done . … He was guiding his cadres on the street , potentially , for violence. ” Another headache for the Obama administration : the coup could result in a cutoff of U.S. economic assistance to Egypt .
